Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2007 10:45AM Fireweed wrote: Go back and read Melissa's "just diagnosed" post above. Get a copy of your pathology report and read her "understanding your pathology report" as well. Breath! Ask you best friend to take you out to dinner. I found it helped to think about one thing at a time. I didn't worry about radiation until the surgery was finished and didn't make a decision about long term medication until radiation was done. Good luck! It gets better.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2007 11:07AM Fireweed wrote: Stop taking the Valium! It does nothing for pain and obviously it is sedating you. Many women transition to Tylenol or ibuprofen by a week out, but just try a few days without Valium first.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 09:32AM Fireweed wrote: I think I opted for the lumpectomy because my surgeon was horrified at the thought of a mastectomy for a small DCIS. If your DCIS (like mine) is high grade, radiation will probably be recommended ater lumpectomy. You will find many women on this forum who chose bilateral mastectomy after a DCIS diagnosis. This seems like a lot of surgery for a relatively minor problem to me. You will be in a better position when you see the pathology report after surgery. And please check the DCIS section below.

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2008 02:46PM Fireweed wrote: I doubt tamoxofen has anything to do with soreness under your arm - did you have a sentinel node biopsy there? Memory loss is known to be a problem with tamoxofen - I've lost two ID tags, one television remote, and two gloves (different pairs of course) in the last couple weeks alone!
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen kpthfaith2 iodine

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 01:44PM Fireweed wrote: I found pain after a partial mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy was not a big deal. I put some ice on it, took pain pills for a day, and went back to work. It helped me to worry about one thing at a time. Waiting for surgery I didn't think about or try to learn about radiation, for example. Most women work through most of their breast cancer treatment. It isn't easy, and you will probably need some time off. It helps to hand off very specific chores to family and friends. I had friends bring me lunch and dinner, enjoy lunch with me, then weed my garden before they left! Have an answer ready for anyone who says "How can I help?". It gets better! The begining is the worst part.
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed grannie pgiglio

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2007 02:30AM Fireweed wrote: People often worry about this. You are not radioactive after treatment - except in the rare case when radioactive seeds are left in your breast. (This is very unusual with breast cancer.) Enjoy your daughter and your grandbaby!

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2007 02:35PM Fireweed wrote: Always appeal the claim! And make sure the doctor's office appeals it as well, and supplies all the appropriate information. Your chance that they made an error or will change their minds is excellent. And I have found hospital billing departments very helpful about reducing charges or setting up payment plans - but you do have to ask. Never pay the first bill they send you! Good luck.

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2007 04:23PM Fireweed wrote: The twitches are called "fasiculations" and are a common symptom of stress. I know "don't worry" doesn't help. Can you ditract yourself with a quick trip somewhere, and interesting book, or a new craft project? Hope everything turns all right.
Posts.Title: anxiety question terri01 iodine

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2007 04:52PM Fireweed wrote: Determined! Ativan is a mild sedative and most people do well with it. What a nice doctor- a rehearsal is a great idea! I'd suggest taking it before you arrive at the hospital - and have a second one with you if you need it. The wire is very very thin. All the breast stuff was done with me lying face down on a table, one tit in a hole, and people underneath doing things to it! Sounds awful, but I never saw the needles and that was helpful.
Posts.Title: Help me understand this surgery Determined1 portiasproudmom

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2007 01:56PM - edited Sep 7, 2007 01:58PM by Fireweed Yes, this will be a long day. Ask for sedation (I wish I had!). Waiting around is worse than any of the procedures. Injection: A radioative tracer will be injected into your breast, probably right under the nipple. It stings and burns intensely for about a second. Then you sit around while your lymph system distributes the tracer to the nodes. Scan: Painless. MRI locates the node/s that picked up the tracer. You will see them on the screen. Their location will be marked with a magic marker on your skin. MRI needle: Your breast will be injected with a local anesthetic. This stings, too. The wire will be inserted into the cavity or the mass the MRI identifies. I didn't feel the wire insertion at all, but my breast did feel tender while I waited for the next step. Don't look - too weird! Lumpectomy: Will go right in the same site. One of more of the sentinal nodes will be removed and checked immediately. It any are positive, the surgeon will go ahead to remove all the axillary nodes. You will wake up with a separate incision under your arm. I admit I didn't listen when this was explained to me and I was alarmed by everything. Good luck and let us know how it goes!

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2008 03:39PM Fireweed wrote: I had partial breast radiation - outside a trial. (In general care is better INSIDE a trial!) I was very happy to get it over in a week with no skin problems. The radiologist says he has had surprisingly few takers when he explained that the stage three trials were still underway, but I'm not really a worrier. It all went great.
